Settlers used fences to contain their livestock in order to prevent them from wandering off and to protect them from predators and thieves. Fences also helped to establish land boundaries and property lines, which was crucial for maintaining order and stability in the American West. Additionally, fences were used to prevent conflicts between neighboring ranchers over grazing land and water rights. Fences were a practical and necessary tool for managing the vast open spaces of the American West. [1, 2]

Fences also helped to establish a sense of permanence and investment in the land.; [1, 2]

Preventing overgrazing was important for settlers because it helped preserve the quality of the grass for their livestock to feed on.
